editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE SIR WILLIAM CECILL KNIGHT, LORDE BVRGHLEY, Lordhigh Trea≈øurer of England, and of hir Maie≈øties mo≈øt Honorable priuy Coun≈øell.
div.p: HAuing by your Honorable meane (my good Lord) obteined, at the hands of my ≈øacred SOVEREIGNE, gratious pa≈ø≈øe, & priuiledge, for mine intended labours, the de≈øcription of famous ENGLAND. I cannot but, in dutie, render vnto your Honor, condigne thanks, and withall diligence, and dutifull endeuour, proceed therein: hoping, that although (in regarde of my long ≈øicknes & other impediments) this beginning carrie not ≈øo ab≈øolute perfection, as in your wi≈øedome may be required: yet may I enioy your patient directions, and gratious a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, I ≈øhall effect the re≈øidue more fully to an≈øwere Honorable expectation.

closer.signed: Your Honors in all dutie, IO. NORDEN

div.head: TO THE CONSIDERATION OF THE HONORABLE, WISE, AND LEARNED.
div.p: ALthough I cannot but confe≈ø≈øe that I am the vnwoorthie≈øt of manie in this lande, (and e≈øpeciallie in the≈øe daies of ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing knowledge) to vndertake (after other farre more de≈øeruing) ≈øo commendable a labor: which requireth arte, indu≈øtrie, learning, countenance, and charge, wherewith I am not ≈øo fullie furni≈øhed as ≈øome other. Yet it may plea≈øe you (in fauour) to accept of my willingnes, and beare with my wants: And the rather for that it hath beene helde heeretofore an excu≈øe (in curte≈øie) Velle bene, though in this age (more ripe in experience) is expected, Optim√® perficere: which neither, altogither e≈øcapeth without emulation: I, as ouercome with a de≈øire to take pains to profite my Countrey, re≈øt vndoubtfull, that the wi≈øe, and learned, will not onely tollerate, but in fauour accept this ≈øimple beginning.

The fruits of my trauell tend not alone to my ≈øelfe in priuate, but to the publike ea≈øe of many. In lieu whereof, my hope and de≈øire is, that he that can reprooue, will friendly reforme what he findeth iu≈øtly faultie. So ≈øhall my proceedings grow to more perfection: and I by all endeuour will ≈øeeke to accompli≈øh what may an≈øwere di≈øcret affections.

div.head: Aduerti≈øements touching the v≈øe of this labor.
div.p: IT is to be noted, that for your ea≈øe I haue in the list of the Map of the Shire, ≈øet downe certaine deui≈øions, letters, and figures: the deui≈øions are in ≈øteed of a ≈øcale of the miles, the le≈ø≈øer coÃÑ taining one, the greater two miles. The letters and figures ≈øerue for the pre≈øent finding of any place de≈øired in the Map, which places are found in the Alphabet with the letter and figure that direct to the place de≈øired. A matter of ≈øo great facilitie as needeth no example.
He that de≈øireth to know the distance betweene places in the Map without compa≈ø≈øes, the v≈øe of the cro≈ø≈øing lines, which ≈øerue for a vniuer≈øall ≈øcale through the Map, an≈øwereth his de≈øire.

Whereas in the collection of the Alphabeticall table, there are heere and there di≈øper≈øed hou≈øes of Nobility & Gentrie. I craue fauorable con≈øideration, though I haue not ≈øo narrowly acquired their interestes, as that may a≈ø≈øure me, that they be all the true ownoures in fee, of the places which they are re≈øident in, which thing to ob≈øerue; as it doth not meerely appertaine to my purpo≈øe, So were it a matter intricate, and the more, for that information (often vncertaine) mu≈øt be of nece≈ø≈øitie, the chiefe≈øt guide therein. Such therefore as I conceiue mo≈øt doubtfull for want of certaine certificat, I haue noted with two ≈øtarres thus, **.

Al≈øo in this commencement of my trauailes, I haue ob≈øerued certain funeral monuments with the armes (if any theron re≈øt vndefaced) which if it may be fauorably conceiued, I ≈øhall with more diligence ob≈øerue the like hereafter, whereby may be pre≈øerued in perpetuall memory, that which time may deface, and ≈øwallow vp in obliuion. Al≈øo by this ob≈øeruation, many may be certified of the places where their aunce≈øtors and allies are interred, and by the coates finde out their vnknowne kinred.

div.head: A BRIEFE DECLARATION OF THE TITLES, INHABITANTS, DIVISIONS, AND SCITVATION OF ENGLAND or BRITANNIA maior: a nece≈ø≈øary introduction to our Speculum Britanniae.
div.p:
NOtwith≈øtanding it re≈øteth vncertaine, how, when, and by whom, this our BRITANNIA was fir≈øt peopled, yet to ≈øatisfie ≈øuch as expect the iudgements, and opinions of ≈øome auncient writers concerning the ≈øame:Bero≈øus in Chald. ant. Annius in Bero≈ø. Cae≈øar. Com. I thinke it not impertinent to ≈øcite the affirmation ofSome ≈øu≈øpect that the hi≈øtorie of Bero≈øus, was but counterfeit, fal≈øly fathered vpon hu name, & therefore helde of no great authoritie. Bero≈øus, who ≈øaith that Samothes called al≈øo Me≈øech, brother to Gomer and Tuball, called al≈øo Dis, the ≈øixt ≈øonne of Iaphet, the ≈øonne of Noah, came into this land about 252. yeres after the floud: who called it Samothea, 3593. yeeres pa≈øt: in which name it continued vntill Albion, the ≈øonne of Neptune, (who di≈øcended of Cham) entred the ≈øame, and chaunged the name of Samothea into ALBION. This Alb√¨on raigned about 562. Ringman. in de≈ø Europae. yeeres after the floud: in the yeere of the worlds creation 2219. 3340. yeeres ≈øince. Plinie calleth it ALVION. Ptolomey
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .
Strabo Munster, and others,Mun≈øt. Co≈øm. will haue it ALBION ab albis rupibus, of the white ≈øea clifes, which are in the ≈øouth coa≈øt of the lande:

Some others will haue it come of the Greeke worde Olbion, Olbion. Cowp. in Dict. which ≈øignifieth felix happie, in regarde of their happines belike that fir≈øt atchiued it. So doth Strabo call Albania, Strabo lib. 4. wherein he placeth the people Cauca≈øiae: felicem habitatu regionem, a happie countrie to dwell in. So is Gothia in the countrey language ierra bona, a good countrey. Some will haue it ALBION of Albina Diocle≈øians daughter, which hath no pr√≥babilitie.Caxton.

It continued in the name of ALBION 608. yeeres, vntill Brytus or Brutus Iulius, arriuall, who conquered the ≈øame about the yeere of the worldes creation 2828. 2734.Brutes arriuall. Galf. Monum. Bale Cent. 1. This Brute changed the name of ALBION into BRYTANE, and the people Albionds into Britans; or after ≈øome BRVTAYNE of the ≈øame Brute ‚Ä¢ y, being turned into v.

Some will haue it BRITANNIA of Brytona a nymph of Greece:Britanniae. others rather holde that it ≈øhoulde take that name of a ≈øeperation, as M.Twinus in Com.
Twine in his Commentaries, who ≈øaith, Britannia is ≈øo called, for that it is Locus diuor≈øio ≈øeparatus ab eo cui adhae≈øerat: a place ≈øeuered from another whereunto it was annexed: and the more to fortifie his rea≈øon, he coniectureth that this Britannia (nowe an apparant I≈øland) was ≈øomtime Penin≈øula annexed vnto the maine of Fraunce; which no doubt is true, but not ≈øince the generall inundation, (by probabilitie) whereby infinite chanels were eaten in the earth, with the rage of ≈øo violent a floud, and con≈øequently many I≈ølands di≈øper≈øed as we ≈øee in the main Ocean, and middle earth ≈øeas: for ≈øurely if it had beene Penin≈øula, or Istmus ≈øince the floud,Plinie. Plinie who liued neere 1500. yeeres before M. Twyne woulde haue as well mentioned ≈øuch a conjunction, as that part of the ≈øea which runneth betweene England and Calleys, which he calleth Mare Ge≈ø≈øoriacum, Mare Ge≈ø≈øoriacuÃÑ. and which Ptolomey calleth Oceanus Britannicus. But it ≈øeemeth that M. Twyne ≈øtandeth vpon the opinion of Antonius Vol≈øcus a Poet, who dreameth of a pa≈ø≈øage fiue miles in bredth betweene England and Fraunce: from whom al≈øo Seruius Honoratus ≈øeemeth to ≈øay,Seruius Honoratus. that BRITANNIA was Olim iuncta continenti, our Brytaine was ioined to the maine continent: which ≈øecrets pa≈ø≈øe our apprehen≈øion.

Sir Thomas Eliot will haue Britannia to be Pritania: Humfrey Lloyd al≈øo ≈øeemeth to ≈øay it ≈øhould be Prid-caine which ≈øignifieth beautifull or white of colour,S. Th. Eliot. Humf. Lloyde. though the c be omitted for more ea≈øier pronunciation, which maketh it Pridaine.

Againe, ≈øome will haue it come of Brith a briti≈øh worde, which ≈øignifieth painted, which coÃÑiecture I take to come of Cae≈øars words, where he ≈øaith,Cae≈øar Com. lib. 4. Omnes Britanni glasto ≈øe inficiunt, all the Brytons be≈ømere them≈øelues, and ≈øtaine their bodies with oade: of which worde Brith and tania a Greeke worde which ≈øignifieth Regnum a kingdome, it is ≈øuppo≈øed to be aptly called Brithtania, the countrey or kingdome of the Brithtons or depainted people.

Goropius Becanus ≈øeemeth to hold another opinion, that it ≈øhould be Bridania, Goropius Becanus. M. Camden. wherof M. Camden maketh con≈øtruction, that Bri in Bridania ≈øhould be free, and ≈øo to make it Fredania, or Free-denmarke.

Thus is our Britannia forced to ≈øu≈øtaine ≈øundry titles vnder one truth,The ≈øeuerall titles of Brytaine. as Brytannia, Pritania, Prid-caine or Pridayne, Brithtania, Brutania, Bridania, and ≈øuch like: according to as manie ≈øundrie mens conceits. But were not Brute ≈øo generally reiected in the≈øe our daies, I could verie ea≈øely be drawne to a≈ø≈øure me that it might be mo≈øt truely Brutania of Brute the ≈øuppo≈øed conquerour, and that Greeke worde tania a kingdome, though Brute were no Greeke, yet might he fitly conioyne this worde tania vnto his name Brute, and ≈øo conclude it Brutania, Brutania. Bruti regnum, the kingdome of Brute,
u being nowe turned into i, as in other wordes, Pe≈ø≈øumus is nowe written Pe≈ø≈øimus, ≈øo are manie other Latine words. Manie of late yeeres reiect the hy≈øtorie of Brute, among others, an Abbot ≈øometime of S. Albons, Iohn of Wheatham≈øted, Io. de Wheathamp≈øt. who wrote about the yere of Chri≈øt, 1443. who ≈øaith plainly, that Totus proce≈ø≈øus de Bruto illo, e≈øt Poeticus, potius quam historicus: The whole matter of that Brute is Poeticall, (fabulous) rather than a true hy≈øtorie. This author liuing of late daies affoordeth reproofe of the mo≈øt auncient. But what antiquitie hath left, and wee by tradition haue receiued, Ip≈øe ≈øciolus, dare not ab≈øolutelie denie, vppon anie mans bare coniecture.
It is at this day called ENGLAND, Anglorum terra, England. the land of Angles, or Engli≈øhmen, the Latins call it Anglia, and the French Angle terre.

The Angli or Engli≈øhmen inhabited part of Germanie whom (as I take it) Ptolomey calleth Angili:
Angili. Ptolomey. and placeth them betweene the Ca≈øuari, & the Chemae, neer the riuer Vi≈øurgis, now We≈øer, in that countrey which is now Westphalia: Cae≈ø. Com. who (as Cae≈øar ≈øaith) Praedae ac belli inferendi cau≈øa, ex Belgis tran≈øierunt, came out of Belgia the lowe Countries, to ≈øeeke releefe, and to war with the Britons: inuading mo≈øt e≈øpecially that part of the lande which borders vppon the ≈øouth ea≈øt, or Germaine ≈øea, as Kent, Su≈ø≈øex, & E≈ø≈øex.Beda. The Angles or Engli≈øhmen inhabited Cambridge≈øhire, I≈øle of Elie, Norffolke and Suffolke; all which was called Eastanglia, and the people East Angles, The Saxons which came al≈øo with the Angles were di≈øper≈øed and ≈øeated in other quarters of the lande, as by the deui≈øion, and Heptarchie it will appeere.

The Saxons and Angles draue the Britons into Wales,Aun. dom. 620. and Cornewall, and other places of refuge. And Egbert king of the we≈øt Saxons became ≈øole Monarch of the whole land, and called the ≈øame England, of that part of Germany wherof he was, wherin the Angili or Angles inhabited.
Some other will haue it England of Anglia, Anglia. the name of a Queene, ≈øometime of this Countrey. But what, whence, or when ≈øhe was they ≈øeeme not to report.

Others will haue it Anglia, ≈øcytuate as it were in Angulo in a corner, or newke by it ≈øelfe. Which opinion is not altogither to be reiected, for that Iulius Solinus ≈øaith,Iulius Solinus. that the ≈øea coa≈øt of Gallia had beene the ende of the worlde, but that the I≈øle of Britaine, (which ≈øtandeth alone as it were in an angle) for the largenes thereof, de≈øerueth the name of another worlde, being ≈øeperated from the re≈øt of the earth, as Virgil ≈øaith, Penitus toto diui≈øos orbe Britannos. Io≈øephus in the oration of king Agrippa ≈øaith, Io≈ø. lib. 2. cap. 26, bel. Iud. The Romaines ≈øought another world, beyond the great Ocean, ≈øending their ho≈øtes into Britayne. And Aegi≈øpus ≈øaith, The Romaines by ≈øtrength gat another
world beyond the Ocean in Britaine far from them.
Allgi≈ø. lib. 2. de excid. Hier. Ant. Vol≈øc.
Antonius Vol≈øcus affirmeth, Pelopone≈øum to be Vlt√¨mum orbem, Br√¨tann√¨am ver√≤ alterum orbem: So that it may be ≈øaide it ≈øtandeth in Angulo, yet it ≈øeemeth not thereof to be called Anglia.
This our famous BRITANNIA (of it ≈øelfe another world) for the firtilitie and plea≈øantnes thereof, hath been ≈øought for, conquered, and inhabited of many ≈øundrie nations.

The fir≈øt as ≈øome dreame were Aborigines ≈øuch people as the earth it ≈øelfe,Aborigines. without humaine propagation brought foorth: who belike followe Ouid,
Ouid metamor. who ≈øaith, Caetera diuer≈øis tellus animalia formis. ≈øponte ≈øuo peperit, &c. But to ≈øay that men ≈øhould ≈øpring of the earth ≈øince Adam di≈øagreeth from the word of God, whereby we learne that God created them male and female, to increa≈øe & multiply, & to gouerne all other earthly creatures. There were a people in Italie,Aborigines in Italie. and they of very great antiquitie: yet not begotten or ≈øprong of the earth, but becau≈øe they were Vagi, and Sine laribus, wanderers vpon the earth without hou≈øe or home, voide of all ciuilitie; & becau≈øe they were vnknowne from whom they de≈øcended, they were accounted Nullorum filii, the children of no fathers, as the Romanes who blu≈øh not to ≈øay they are Deorum filii, de≈øcended of the Gods. Such might be in this land at the Britons ariuall;Giants in EnglaÃÑd. Britons. Ann. mundi 2855 Deut. 1.28. which might bee counted Indigenae, Vagi, vnciuill, and therefore called Giants, as were the Anakimes mentioned in the Scripture.

But to leaue the≈øe vnknowne people;Yuand. Do. Tolo≈ø. lib. de genel. Iapheth. Yuandus writeth that our Britannia was inhabited fir≈øt by Babylonians: But it is not to be denied that the Britons, (whereof ≈øoeuer ≈øo named) were the fir≈øt that vnder ciuill regiment po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed this land.Romanes. After them the Romans, whom Iulius Cae≈øar fir≈øt conducted hither: & after him Claudius the Emperor came into this land with his Romanes about Anno Chri≈øti 40.Iulius Cae≈øar. Claudius imperat. Pictes, Scots. Beede. M. Camden. Scots afflict the Britons. After the Romanes came the Pictes and Scots out of Scythia (as Beede reporteth.) But M. Camden taketh them to bee Britons which fled into the north parts for feare of the Romanes. The Scots po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the North parts of Britaine, Albania nowe Scotland, greatly afflicted the Britons, of the South, who craued aide of the Saxons, and they with the Angles ariuing: in proce≈ø≈øe of time ≈øubdued the Britons, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the lande, driuing the Britons into Cambria now Wales, into Cornewall and other places of refuge,Ann. Dom. 1012. Danes. William duke of Normandy with his Normans. about the yeere of Chri≈øt, 430. Then came the Danes, and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed the Saxons neere 200. yeeres. La≈øtlie the Normans vnder the conduct of William duke of Normandie, who vnder a pretended title ≈øubiected this lande vnto him≈øelfe about the yeere of Chri≈øt 1066. by which conque≈øt he is intituled WILLIAM the CONQVEROR, who inforced all the inhabitants to ≈øweare vnto him fealtie, faith, and true allegeaunce, and being
quietlie ≈øetled in his kingdome, cau≈øed this land to be de≈øcribed and exactly ≈øurueied about the 15. yeere of his raigne, William Conqueror cau≈øed England to be de≈øcribed and ≈øurueied. Doomes day book. wherein he cau≈øed to be ob≈øerued, how many hides of land, there were in his kingdome, the value of euery hide, and who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it: which ≈øuruey re≈øteth in record at We≈øtmin≈øter in a booke called Doomes day, or the role of Winchester. The v≈øuall account of lande at this day in Englande is by acres, yardes, carewes, hydes, knightes fees, cantreds, baronies and counties.

Xiphilinus diuideth this land into Britanniam Superiorem, Ex Dione. England how deuided. & Inferiorem: Ptolomey into Magnam & Paruam: Sextus Rufus, who liued vnder the Emperor Valentinian, hath Britanniam primam, & ≈øecundam flauiam, and Maximam Cae≈øarien≈øem, another part added called Valentia, remembred by Marcellinus. It was al≈øo deuided into Loegria, Cambria, and Albania, called al≈øo Caledonia, which are nowe England, Wales, and Scotland.
It was deuided into ≈øeauen kingdomes by the Saxons, after, into Prouinces, Shires or Counties, all which were enhabited by people of ≈øeuerall names after Ptolomey, as may appeere.

list.head: CAMBRIA, WALES, inhabited by the Brit∆øea las or WALLI BRITANNI, is deuided into 13. ≈øhires.

div.p: The former Heptarchie, or Countrie of 7. kingdomes,The Heptarchie now a Monarchy. nowe a Monarchie, mo≈øt happely gouerned by the ≈øole Empres thereof mo≈øt renowmed Queene ELIZABETH, was deuided into the former prouinces,Aluredus deuided the ≈øhires of England. H. 8. of Wales. ≈øhieres or counties by ALVREDVS the fourth ≈øonne of ADOLPHVS, & brother to ETHELDRED, who raigned in the yeere of Chri≈øt 872. But Cambria, now Wales, was di≈øtingui≈øhed by ≈øhieres, by the famous king HENRY the eight: all which ≈øhieres were deuided into certain parts, which the Saxons called √∞rihingaf which we cal le√æs or lathes,Shires deuided in √∞rihingaf or le√æs. Ridings. the≈øe deui≈øions are yet in Kent: and Yorke≈øhire at this day is diuided into Rydings, which may be al≈øo called √∞rihingaf, all which parts conteine in them certain Hundreds, in euerie of which was conteined ten teo√æunges, of vs called Tithings, conteining ten men,Hundreds. wherof it was called al≈øo tienmentale, a colledge or corporation of ten men,Teothongs. & the officer of this Tithing the Saxons called teo√æungmon, of vs (e≈øpeciallie in the We≈øt) a Tythingman: in ≈øome places, as in Northampton≈øhire, a Therdbarrow:Therdbarrowes. ≈øo that ten of the≈øe Tithings yeelded a 100. men, whereof the Engli≈øh call it at this day a Hundred (though the number of the men be now vncertaine) the Latines call it Centuria. In ≈øteede of Tithings, (e≈øpecially beyonde Trent,) they haue WapeÃÑtaches,Centuriae. Wapentaches. which the Saxons called ∆øe∆øontacs, which tooke that name of the view of weapons, and where the Tenaunts deliuered vp their weapons vnto their Lords.Bore≈øealdor. The officers of the≈øe petite deui≈øions or Tythings, are in Kent called BorHesealdors, the chiefe≈øt or elde≈øt pledges as M.M. Lamberde. Lamberde mo≈øt expert in the Saxon toung affirmeth.

The word Shire commeth of the Saxon Verbe Scyran,Shire why ≈øo called. which ≈øignifieth to cut or to deuide. Euerie of the≈øe Shires in time pa≈øt was gouerned per Comitem, whom we now call Earle, who was qua≈øi praefectus regius, the kings Lieuetenant, who of the Saxons was called Eorle, of whom euery Shire is called a Countie, a Comite, Counties why ≈øo called. of the Earle. But of later time there haue been, and are yeerely cho≈øen in euery ≈øhire, an officer by the Prince, which in Latine is called Vicecomes, as one appointed vice Comitis in the Earles ≈øteed,The Sherife what and whence ≈øo called. we call him the Sherife, the Saxons called him Scyregerefa, the Reeue of the Shire, for gerefa is an officer to collect rents, and other reuenues, and to execute things vnder, & for another,
the Germaines at this daie haue Burgreeue of the Saxons ∆øortgerefa,Manie ≈øortes of Reeues. the Mayor of a Towne, Margreeues, whom we cal Waterbaylifes: a Land≈øgreue whom we call the Reeue of a Mannor.

Pliny, Gildas Solinus, and Martianus do agree, that this our BRITANNIA MAIOR is 800.The length of Brytaine and the bredth. miles in length, including al≈øo Scotland: and Martianus ≈øaith, it is in bredth 300. miles: in which dimen≈øuration they ≈øeeme to account after the Italian mea≈øure, which is le≈ø≈øe then our myles:The ≈øuppo≈øed breadth & length of Englande by ≈øtatute mea≈øure. yet were England mea≈øured according to the true and exact men≈øuration prouided and allowed by ≈øtatute, it woulde appeere to be of greater length & breadth, then the≈øe authors account. An Italian mile containeth mille pa≈ø≈øus maiores, or Geometricos a 1000.A myle A furlong. A pearch. paces of fiue foote to the pace, which is al≈øo a fadome. And our Engli≈øh mile is eight furlongs, euery furlong 40. pearches, euery pearch 16. foote, and halfe, which maketh 5280. foote, which is more then the Italian mile by 56. paces. But our ordinary mile exceedeth both the ItaliaÃÑ, & true Engli≈øh mile.

The forme of this land is Trianguler,The fertilitie of England. much like Cicilia an I≈øland in the middle earth ≈øea. The center of this land which I take to be about Titburie ca≈øtle, hath latitude about 52. degrees, 50. minuts, and longitude 21. degrees 28. minuts. This our BRITANNIA for the fertility & fruitfulnes therof, matcheth the be≈øt, yeelding ≈øuch generall commodities, & in ≈øuch abundance, that it may be ≈øaid:
Albion emporiis, tellus opulenta marinis,
fertilis omnigenum rerum:
Another ≈øaith,
Anglia non ≈øegetes effundit diuite vena?
Pa≈øcua non pingui fertilitate tument?
In gremio fluuiis riui mi≈øcentur amaenis,
Gurgitibus rapidis & vada pura meant.
Nobilis antiquo nutat cum robore quercus.
Et nemorum grato ≈øpirat odore viror.
Vi≈øceribus mediis errant pretio≈øa metalla,
Diuitiae cre≈øcunt intus, ope≈øque foris.
It were too long to recite the particuler fruites, and rare commodities it yeeldeth, all which are knowne to the worlde, as the Co≈ømographicall Poet ≈øaith, Omnia ≈øunt famatotuÃÑ vulgata per orbem.

And aboue all other ble≈ø≈øings it hath greate≈øt cau≈øe to reioyce in the free v≈øe of the true knowledge of Chri≈øt,England most happie in the v≈øe of the Go≈øpell. wherein it triumpheth aboue all other kingdomes or Countries of the world, mo≈øt happely therin maintained, (vnder the mightie king of kings, cele≈øtiall lehouah) by the ≈øacred hand of the mo≈øt imperial Queene ELIZABETH, the fruits of who≈øe happie raigne who can enioy, & not vnfeinedly commend hir ≈øafetie, and happie continuance, vnto that all ≈øufficient God, who beyond expectation, in fauour, commended hir to vs? in regarde whereof our Englande may be truely called OLBION a happie Countrie.

div.head: SPECVLVM BRITANIAE.
The first part, conteining a briefe Historicall and Chorographicall di≈øcription of MYDDLESEX.
div.p: HAuing thus briefely touched the generall, I purpo≈øe to proceede to the particular de≈øcriptions of this out BRITANIA: wherein (imitating the artificial Painter, who beginneth alwaies at the head, the principall part of the bodie:) I thought it not vnfit to begin my Speculum Britaniae with MYDDLESEX,The cau≈øes why Myddle≈øex is the first part of Speculum Britaniae. which aboue all other Shyres is graced, with that chiefe and head Citie LONDON: which as an adamant draweth vnto it all the other parts of the land, and aboue the re≈øt is mo≈øt v≈øuallie ferquented with hir Maie≈øties mo≈øt regall pre≈øence.

div.head: Of MIDDLESEX, and of the Trinobantes.
div.p: IT is called MIDDLESEX of the middle Saxons, Myddle≈øex why ≈øocalled. for that they inhabited that part betweene the East Saxons, West Saxons, and South Saxons.

MIDDLESEX was a percel of that countrey wherin (as Cae≈øar ≈øaith) dwelled the Trinobantes whom Ptolomy calleth Trinoantes, omitting the b. Myddle≈øex parte of the Trinobantes. Cae≈øar Com. Ptolomey. Galfr. Moun. ≈øome call them Trinouantes, putting u. for b.

The chiefe Citie of the≈øe Trinobantes, was then called Trinobantum, Colche≈øter. London the Citie of the Ea≈øt Saxons and Trinobantes. Corn. Tacitus. of ≈øome held to be Colchester of ≈øome London; Beede ≈øaith that London was the chiefe Citie of the East Saxons, If ≈øo, then of nece≈ø≈øitie, of the Middle ≈øaxons, and con≈øequently of the Trinobantes; yet Tacitus ≈øaith, that London was not Trinobantum; nor the people Trinobantes, neere London, and his rea≈øon is that if the Trinobantes had beene neere London, they would not haue ≈øuffered Suetonius to haue pa≈ø≈øed thither; which argument Humfrey Lloyde ≈øeemeth to confute in this manner.Humf. Lloyd. The Trinobantes (≈øaith he) being Suetonius enemies, would haue as well preuented him in the inner part of the countrey, as neere London, con≈øidering that Suetonius came from the I≈øle of Angle≈øey, marching through the whole countrey. So that in what place ≈øoeuer the Trinobantes were re≈øident, they could not be ignorant of his pa≈ø≈øage.

Polydore Virgile, Pollidore. a man of no great credite, as touching his hi≈øtorie, affirmeth from ≈øome other that Trinobantum was Northampton, and the Northampton≈øhire men Trinobantes, Northampton Tranton. and his rea≈øon is for that the countrey men in their language called that place Tranton, which hath no ≈øuch ≈øemblable con≈øonance with Trinobantum that he, or any other, ≈øhould ≈øeeke Trinobantum in that part of Britaine.

Ma≈øter Camden, M. Camden. a ≈øinguler ≈øcrutator of antiquities ≈øeemeth to hold (but not ab≈øolutely) that the Trinobantes ≈øhould be ≈øo called, of the bryti≈øh word Trenant, which ≈øignifieth townes ≈øcytuate in the valley.Cae≈øar. But Cae≈øar ≈øaith, they inhabited Prope firmi≈ø≈øimam earum regionum ciuitatem, neere the mo≈øt ≈øtronge≈øt Citie in tho≈øe countries; which as I take was London.

div.head: The lymites and principall bounds of MYDDLESEX.
div.p: MYDDELSEX is ≈øcituate in the ≈øouth ea≈øt parte of this lande, bordering vpon the north, vpon Hertford≈øhire. On the ea≈øt vpon E≈ø≈øex, Lea riuer. devided thence by the riuer Lea, and the Meere ditch: on the ≈øouth vpon Surrey, hauing the mo≈øt famous riuer Thami≈øe, the bound and lymite betweene them, and on the We≈øt vpon Buckingham ≈øhire, Colne riuer and the Shire ditch, being the deui≈øion betweene them.

That famous riuer which is commonly of vs called Temes, is of Ptolemey called Iame≈øa ae≈øtuarium, Ptolemey. Plin. lib. 2. cap. 3. Iame≈øa ae≈øtuariuÃÑ. of Plinie Iame≈øais; of Cae≈øar Tame≈øis. It ≈øeemeth to be compact of two names of riuers, Tame and I≈øe, which two riuers meete neere Wallingford in Barke≈øhire, where after a familier manner, they louingly conioyne and vnite them ≈øelues, and after a kinde of Matrimoniall order, of two they become one Tame, Thami≈øe of Tame and I≈øe. and I≈øe, becommeth Thami≈øe holding that name, growing more and more famous, vntill with great pride it ≈øaluteth the maine ≈øea. The like coniunction of names is in Palestina or the holy land, Iordan of Ior and Dan. where that famous riuer Iardan, is compact of Iar, which ri≈øeth neere Mara, towardes Dama≈øcus, and Dan which ri≈øeth neere, and taketh name of the Citie of Dan, both ri≈øing out of the mountaines Lybanon, and meete at Cae≈øaria Philippi, where, the≈øe two Iar, and Dan, become Iardan, as the Poet ≈øaith.Hunt. Co≈øm. Iordanni≈øque ≈øacer geminis √® fontibus ortus.
The riuer of Thami≈øe ebbeth and floweth as farre as Richmond, ≈øometime farther, ≈øome time not ≈øo farre, neere ≈øixtie miles from the maine ≈øea.
It hath beene ob≈øerued and affirmed by ≈øome that this riuer doth not ea≈øely increa≈øe with land waters. Sit experientia Iudex.

The riuer Lea, of the Saxons lig a is a proper riuer, heretofore, Lea riuer nauigable in time pa≈øt(as ≈øome affirme) nauigable, and that ≈øhipping pa≈ø≈øed through the ≈øame, from the Thami≈øe to Hartford. Barges haue of late pa≈ø≈øed that way, to Ware, which was granted by Acte of Parliament about the eighteene yeer of the raigne of Queene ELIZABETH, but for ≈øome cau≈øes of late di≈øcontinued. This riuer for the mo≈øt part deuideth MIDDLESEX and East≈øex. But there is a ditch called the Meere ditch, about two miles and a halfe in length,Meere ditch. betweene Waltham abbey, and Higham hill bridge which is cut into the mer≈øhes and pa≈ø≈øeth through the ≈øame, for a di≈øtinction of the boundes betweene the two ≈øhires.

Colne riuer is the deui≈øion between MIDDLESEX and Buckingham ≈øhire, But that a ditch called the Shire ditch, Colne riuer. Shire ditch. which ≈øeemeth to haue been forced into MIDDLESEX, about two miles in length, north of Colnebroke.
Through this riuer as ≈øome affirme, haue pa≈ø≈øed ≈øhipping to Saint Albans. Minime credendum.

div.head: The nature of the ≈øoyle and fertilitie of MYDDLESEX.
div.p: MYDDLESEX is a ≈ømall Shire,The length and circuit of Middle≈øex. in length not twentie myles, in circuite (as it were by the ring) not about 70. myles, yet for the fertilitie thereof, it may compare with any other ≈øhire: for the ≈øoyle is excellent, fat and fertile and full of profite: it yeeldeth corne and graine, not onelie in aboundance,Middle≈øex ≈øertile. but mo≈øt excellent good wheate, e≈øpeciallie about Heston, which place may be called Granarium tritici regalis, He≈øton. for the ≈øingularitie of the corne. The vaine of this e≈øpeciall corne ≈øeemeth to extend from Heston to Harrow on the hill, betweene which as in the mid way, is Periuale, more truely Pureuale. Piriuale or pureuale. In which vale is al≈øo Northold, Southold, Norcote, Gerneford, Hayes, &c. And it ≈øeemeth to extend to Pynner, though with ≈øome alteratioÃÑ of the ≈øoile. It may be noted al≈øo how nature hath exalted Harrow on the hill,Harrow on the hill. which ≈øeemeth to make o≈øtentation of it ≈øcituation in the Pureuale, from whence, towardes the time of Harue≈øt, a man may beholde the fields round about, ≈øo ≈øweetely to addre≈ø≈øe them≈øelues, to the ≈øiocle, and ≈øith, with ≈øuch comfortable aboundaunce, of all kinde of graine, that the husbandman which waiteth for the fruits of his labours, cannot but clap his hands, for ioy, to ≈øee this vale, ≈øo to laugh and ≈øing.

Yet doth not this ≈øo fruitefull ≈øoyle yeeld comfort, to the wayfairing man in the wintertime, by rea≈øon of the claie≈øh nature of ≈øoyle: which after it hath ra≈øted the Autume ≈øhowers, waxeth both
dyrtie and deepe: But vnto the countrie ≈øwaine it is as a ≈øweete and plea≈øant garden, in regard of his hope of future profite, for
The deepe, and dirtie loath≈øome ≈øoyle,
Yeelds golden gaine, to painefull toyle. The indu≈øtrious and painefull husbandman will refu≈øe a pallace, to droyle in the≈øe golden puddles.

This part of MYDDDLESEX may for fertilitie compare with Tandeane, Tandeane. in the we≈øt part of Somer≈øet≈øhire. But that Tandeane, farre ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth it for ≈øundrie fruites, and commodities, which this countrie might al≈øo yeelde, were it to the like imployed: but it ≈øeemeth they onely couet to maintaine their auncient cour≈øe of life, and ob≈øerue the husbandrie of their fathers, without adding, any thing to their greater profite.

This ≈øhire is plentifullie ≈øtored, Middle≈øex bewtified with faire buildinges. and as it ≈øeemeth beautified, with manie faire, and comely buildinges, e≈øpecially of the Merchants of London, who haue planted their hou≈øes of recreation not in the meane≈øt places: which al≈øo they haue cunningly contriued, curiou≈øly beautified, with diuers deui≈øes, neatly decked with rare invencions, inuironed with Orchards of ≈øundrie delicate fruites, gardens with delectable walks, arbers, allees, and great varietie of plea≈øing dainties: all which ≈øeeme to be beautifull ornaments vnto this countrie. But who ≈øo turneth his eies vnto the ≈øtately & mo≈øt princely pallaces of Queene ELIZABETH in many parts of this ≈øhire mo≈øt ≈øweetely ≈øcituate, garni≈øhed with mo≈øt princelie delights, beholding al≈øo the hou≈øes of Nobilitie, may ≈øaie as Vadian of a fruitefull and plea≈øant place in Egypt, Facies istius terre pulcherima est, Vad Co≈øns. &c. The face or ≈øuperficies of this countrey, is mo≈øt beautifull, the fields fre≈øh and greene, the valleyes delightfull to behold, the townes villages and ≈øtately buildings enterlaced with the plea≈øant woodes are glorious to be ≈øeene.

div.head: Of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall and Ciuill gouernment of this Shire.
div.p: FOr matter concerning Church gouernment, and order, this ≈øhire is vnder the iuri≈ødiction of the bi≈øhop of London; which See ≈øometime did belong to the Archbi≈øhop, vntill S. Augu≈øtines time, who was called the Apo≈øtle of Englande, he turned the Archbi≈øhops See from London to Caunterburie, where it continueth.

And whereas all other ≈øhires within this land, for the mo≈øt part, haue a perticular officer yeerely elected by hir Maie≈øtie, called a Sheryfe Shere-Reeue, Sherife of Middle≈øex. or Reeue of the ≈øhire: this ≈øhire by charter made by King IOHN, Quinto Iulii anno regni ≈øui 1. is in
that point, vnder the high officer of the Citic of London the MAIOR: who by force of the ≈øame charter, yeerely con≈øtituteth a Sherife, within the ≈øame: who al≈øo is accountable vnto the ≈øaide Citie for all matters appertaining to his ≈øaid office.
Euerie Alderman that hath beene Maior of London is Iu≈øtice of peace in MYDDLESEX.

div.head: Olde and auncient highwaies now vnaccu≈øtomed.
div.p: THe old and auncient high waie to high Bernet, Port Poole. from Porte-Poole, now Grayes Inne, as al≈øo from Clerkenwell, was through a lane, on the ea≈øt of Pancras Church, called Longwich lane. froÃÑ thence, leauing Highgate on the we≈øt, it pa≈ø≈øed through Tallingdone lane and ≈øo to Crouch ende, Tallingdon lane. and thence through a Parke called Harn≈øey great parke, to Mu≈øwell hill, to Coanie hatch, Fryarne Barnet, and ≈øo to Whetstone, which is now the common high way to high Bernet. This auncient high way, was refu≈øed of wayfaring men, and carriers, by rea≈øon of the deepenes and dirtie pa≈ø≈øage in the winter ≈øea≈øon: In regard whereof it was agreed betweene the Bi≈øhop of London, and the Countrie, that a newe waie ≈øhoulde bee layde forth through the ≈øaid Bi≈øhops parks, beginning at Highgate hill, to leade (as nowe is accu≈øtomed) directly to Whestone: for which newe waie all cartes, carriers, packmen, and ≈øuch like trauellers, yeelde a certaine tole vnto the Bi≈øhop of London, Highgate tole. which is fermed (as is ≈øaid at this daie) at 40. li. per annum. and for that purpo≈øe, was the gate erected on the hill, that through the ≈øame all traueilers ≈øhoulde pa≈ø≈øe, and be the more aptlie ≈øtaide for the ≈øame tole.

Another auncient high waie which did leade to Edgworth, and ≈øo to Saint Albons, was ouer Hampsted heath, and thence to, and through an old lane, called Hendon wante, neere Hendon, Hendon want. through which it pa≈ø≈øed to Edgwoorth, whence it pa≈ø≈øed ouer Brokeley hilles, through part of Hertford≈øhire, by Radnet, Colnestreete, Saint Stephens, and Saint Mychaels, leauing Saint Albons, halfe a mile in the ea≈øt. This way of ≈øome is helde to be Watlingstreete, one of the fower high waies, which Bellinus cau≈øed to be made, & leadeth (as ≈øome affirme) through Watlingstreete in London.

item.p: The men of our time, who more greedelie thir≈øt for high and great preferments, then for the diligent execution of their callings, and feeding of Gods people; may by this godly mans example be mooued, ≈øomthing to mortefie their greedy affections, and onioying onely a ≈øufficient portion, to endeuour rather the building of the Church of God then their owne glory, And in time to ca≈øt away tho≈øe things that hinder their going one, in a ≈øincere cour≈øe of life.

The ≈øaid Lady decea≈øed Anno 1582. hauing i≈ø≈øue, foure daughters, Katherine the elde≈øt maried Henry Earle of Northumberland, who by her had i≈ø≈øue Henry Lord Percie, Thomas, William Charles, Richard, Allyn, Io≈ø≈øalyne and George, Lady Iane, Lucy, and Elinor.

Dorathy the ≈øecond daughter maried ≈øir Thomas Cecill knight, who by hir had i≈ø≈øue William, Richard, Edward, Christopher, and Thomas, Katherine, Lucy, Myldred, Mary, Su≈øan, Elizabeth, Dorathy, and Frances.
Lucy the third daughter maried William Cornwallys E≈øquire by whom ≈øhe had i≈ø≈øue, Thomas and Iohn, Ione, Frances, Elizabeth, and Katherine.
Elizabeth the fir≈øt and younge≈øt daughter maried ≈øir Iohn Danuers knight, by whom ≈øhe had i≈ø≈øue Charles and Henry, Anne, Lucy, Elienor, and Mary.

One Heron E≈øqire founded Hacquenie Church, and lyeth buried in the north Ile,Heron E≈øquire buried. in a toombe of white free ≈øtone his armes appeare ingrauen in ≈øtone in euery piller of the ≈øame Church thus,
In the ≈øame Church in the ≈øouth Ile was buried Roe knight,Roe Alderman buried. ≈øometime Mayor of London, his monument is of marble and Alabla≈øter.

list.item:
Heston, H. 10. a mo≈øt fertyle place of wheate
blazon or coat of arms yet not ≈øo much to be commended for the quantitie, as for the qualitie, for the wheat is mo≈øt pure, accompted the pure≈øt in manie ≈øhires. And therefore Queene ELIZABETH hath the mo≈øt part of her provi≈øion from that place for manchet for her Highnes owne diet, as is reported.

item.p: Houn≈ølow or Hun≈ølow, H. 10. belongeth vnto two pari≈øhes, the north ≈øide of the ≈øtreete to Heston, and the ≈øouth to Istlewoorth: But there is a chappell of ea≈øe, which belonged vnto the fryerie there di≈ø≈øolued, which friery after the di≈ø≈øolutioÃÑ was by exchange giuen to the Lord Wind≈øore, by King Henry the eight. Afterwardes it came to Auditor Roan by purchace who hath be≈øtowed the ≈øame chappell, and 40. ≈øhillings per annum vpon the inhabitantes to the ende and vpon condition that they by farther contribution ≈øhall maintaine a mini≈øter there.
* There is a faire hou≈øe erected where the friery was: belonging to the heires of Auditor Roan.
In the chappell was buried ≈øir George Wind≈øore knight in a monument of white free ≈øtone, ray≈øed with foure pillers.Sir George Wind≈øore buried. In that place lie many other of the Wind≈øores.

list.item: Hanworth I. 10. a hou≈øe of hir Maie≈øties.

item.p:
Hampton Court K. 12. an honour of Queene ELIZABETHES, a mo≈øt regall pallace ≈øtately ray≈øed of bricke after a mo≈øt princely forme, by Cardinall WOVLSEY mo≈øt plea≈øantly, ≈øcytuate vpon delight≈øome Thami≈øe. Queene ELIZABETH hath of late cau≈øed
a very bewtifull fountaine,A fountaine erected at Hampton-court. there to be erected, in the ≈øecond court which graceth the pallace, and ≈øerueth to great and nece≈ø≈øarie v≈øe, the fountaine was fini≈øhed in Anno 1590. not without great charge.

It is called Hampton Court of the pari≈øh of Hampton, Hampton Court why ≈øo called. which ≈øtandeth not far thence: and Court commeth of Curia, which was the place where the Senate of Rome a≈ø≈øembled, and was taken for the Senate it ≈øelfe, And thereof groweth our word Court, which ≈øignifieth all a≈ø≈øemblies either for tryall of controuer≈øies, or con≈øulting of matters of ≈øtate, as al≈øo it is among≈øt vs v≈øed as an adiunct, to diuers hou≈øes in this land of greate≈øt antiquitie, as the mo≈øt auncient hou≈øe in a mannor called the Court hou≈øe. But this word Court is hereunto added neither in regard of antiquitie, nor head hou≈øe of a mannor. But in regard of the Maie≈øtie and Princely bewtie thereof, fit for none but for a King or Queene, who≈øe re≈øidence in any place draweth a Princely a≈ø≈øembly, which is called the Court, for where hir Maie≈øty is re≈øident there is the Court of ≈øtate. This word Court is a mo≈øt common adiunct to places of antiquitie in Artetia, as al≈øo in diuers prouinces of France and el≈øe where as Haplincourt, in Normandy, Bonlayn Court in Champaigne, and Hallcourt neere Amyens.

There are belonging to this princely pallace two parkes, Parkes at Hampton Court. the one of Deare, the other of hares, both inuironed with wals of bricke, the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Deare parke, excepted, which is paled and inuironed with the Thami≈øe.

list.head: I.
list.item: I≈ølington or I≈øeldon E. 20. belonging to a prebend of Paules.
S. Ieames G. 18. hir Maie≈øties, a very ≈øtately hou≈øe, built after a quadranguler forme, by the famous King Henry the eight.

list.head: K.
list.item:
Kylbourne or Keelebourne,
Kylbourne why ≈øo called. E. 16. ≈øeemeth to take name of Keele, and bourn which ≈øignifie colde water: It is called in ≈øome records Kullebourne. In the time of H. the 1. Herbert abbot of Westminster, by permi≈ø≈øion of Gylbert by≈øhop of London, and by con≈øent of the conuent, graunted to 3. Maides the Hermitage there which one Gorbone builded, with all the lande of that place.

list.item: Kingstonwyke, K. 14. It is a Hamlet neere Kingstone vpon Thamis, ≈øtanding in MYDDLESEX, and is ≈øo called,Wike whence deriued. for that it is a rowe of hou≈øes leading into Kingstone, which rowe of hou≈øes in Lattine is called Vicus, in our toong Vyke or Wyke, of the Saxons pyc. Vadianus an excellent Geographer,Vadian Co≈øme. ≈øaith that Vicus in opido via est domorum ≈øeriem complexa, Vike is a way or pa≈ø≈øage in a towne being orderly compact of hou≈øes, which we al≈øo cala ≈øtreete. In Rome are divers of the≈øe ≈øtreetes, as Vicus affricus, Vicus ciprius, & Vicus celeratus, Vicus ≈øceleratus Roma.

list.head: L.

item.p: London, F. 20. the mo≈øt famous Citie in all Brytaine, which Era≈ømus vpon the Proverbe Rhodii ≈øacrificium, ≈øaith, is deducted of Lindus a citie of the Ile of Rhodes, Stephanus calleth it Lyndonium, the Saxons Londenscaster, Londenbiryg Londen∆øyc, Ptolomey, Cornelius Tacitus, and Antonius, Londiniu, and Longidinium, Amianus Londinum: the Welchmen Lundayne, we call it London: Ieffrey of Monmouth, Troia nova, or Ternouantum Newe Troy; ≈øome call it Luddes-Towne of Ludde the elde≈øt ≈øonne of Helie: Leland taketh it to be Trenouans, new Towne, for that in the briti≈øh toong Tre ≈øignifieth a towne: M. Camden ≈øeemeth, in ≈øome ≈øort, to yeelde that it ≈øhould be called London of the Briti≈øh word Lhwn, which ≈øignifieth a woode, or el≈øe he will haue it London or Londinum of the Briti≈øh word Lhong, which ≈øignifieth ≈øhips or ≈øhipping, in regarde that our Thamis yeeldeth ≈øuch apt acce≈ø≈øe for ≈øhips euen to the citie.

This Citie was burned and greatly wa≈øted by the ho≈øt of the pagan Danes, in the time of king Alphred, Greg. in past. London burned. as reporteth Gregory in
his Pa≈øtorale about the yeere of Chri≈øt 872.London reedefied. This Alphred about the yeere 886. in the 35. yeere of his natiuitie reedefied this Citie, beautifieng the ≈øame with faire buildings, and committed the cu≈øtody thereof to Alphred Earle of Mercia, Fabyan. as the ≈øame Gregorie reporteth.

A great part of London was againe burned about the yeere of Chri≈øt 981. At what time it had mo≈øt buildings, from Ludgate towards Westmin≈øter, and little, where the heart of the Citie nowe is, but buildings ≈øcattered heere and there out of forme and order: So that it ≈øeemed inferior to diuers other Cities of this land, as Lincolne, Canterbury, Yorke and others, as by the role of Winche≈øter appeereth. But after the conque≈øt it was reedefied, and by the conquerour greatly increa≈øed, So that by degrees it is become a mo≈øt ample and ≈øtately Citie, far excelling all other in this land.

This Citie was (before the conque≈øt) made by William Duke of Normandy) gouerned by Portreeues, called of the Saxons portgerefas whom the Germans call Burgreues, The gouernement of London. which gouernement Richard the fir≈øt altered, and appoimed two baylifes. Who in the time of King Iohn and by his command were di≈øcharged, for a time, by 35. elders or heads of the Citie, for a contempt again≈øt the King. But they were not long in di≈øgrace, but through their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and the di≈øcreete handling of the matter by the≈øe 35. heads or elders of the Citie, the King not onely forgaue the baylifes, but granted vnto the Citie by his letters pattents, that they ≈øhould yeerely choo≈øe vnto the m≈øelues, a Ma yor which v≈øually is of one of the 12. companies, mentioned in the Map of the Citie, and two Shirifes who haue beene accu≈øtomed to take their oth vpon Saint Mathewes day, nine daies befor Michelmas, and vpon Michelmas day to take their charge, but it is now otherwi≈øe. The fir≈øt Mayor was cho≈øen in the tenth yeere of King Iohn, The first Mayor of Lodnon.
Anno 1209. Euery May or was wont to be pre≈øented to the King where≈øoeuer he was in England, vntill Henrie the thirds time, about Anno 1242. and before the King to be ≈øworne; after that it was referred to the Barons of the Exchequere, and ≈øo continueth to this day. Sir Iohn Allin knight, twice Mayor of London gaue a coller of gold to be ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely worne by the Mayor Anno 1544. In the time of H. 3. al≈øo the Aldermen of the Citie were or deined,Alcermen of London. who tooke rule of the particuler wardes thereof, 25. in number, and the≈øe Aldermen were yeerely changed as are the Shirifes, but now it is otherwi≈øe, which wardes and the pari≈øhes in them are the≈øe.

list.head: Walbrooke warde.

list.head: Beynerdea≈øtle warde.
