S. Genyn within S. Martin le graunde.

list.head: Creplegate warde.
list.item: S. El≈øinge ≈øpittle now a pari≈øh church.

item.p: Other Churches there are within this Citie not mentioned in the wardes, nor v≈øed as pari≈øh Churches: whereof the fir≈øt is Paules, Paules buylded. a mo≈øt ≈øtately temple, builded by Ethelbert king of Kent, anno, 610. who con≈øecrated the ≈øame vnto S. Paule. It was afterward augmented by Mauricius bi≈øhop of London, anno 1107. Henry Lacy Earle of Lincolne, builded the ≈øouth cro≈ø≈øe Ile, & was there buried anno 1310. It is a Cathedrall Chruch the bi≈øhops Sea of London; ≈øometime the archbi≈øhops Sea, but remooued thence to Caunterburie, by the meanes of S. Augustine, at the reque≈øt of the Citizens of Caunterbury. Paules ≈øteeple. In the middell of this famous temple, is a Tower mo≈øt artificially rai≈øed vpon ≈øtrong pillers, verie admirable to be con≈øidered, for that the foundation of the ≈øame maine Tower can not be de≈øerned in the bodie of the Church, and yet a≈øcendeth in great altitude, as it were in the center of the church, not (without curious view) to be ≈øeene, howe it is ≈øupported: vpon this Tower was rai≈øed a Piramis or (as we coÃÑmonly terme it) as Steeple, couered with lead, which is ≈øaide to haue beene in altitude equall with the church in longitude, the height therof is recorded to be 534. foote from the ground: which ≈øtately piramis or ≈øteeple was thrice con≈øumed with fire: Paules ≈øteeple burned three times. fir≈øt in the yeere of Chri≈øt 1087. which was not long after newlie erected: and burned againe anno 1444. after that rai≈øed and againe con≈øumed with fire, by vnknowne meanes (the iudgement of God inkindling it) in the yeere of Chri≈øt 1561. to the terror of the whole Citie: remaining as yet wihtout that ≈øtately ornament.
There lieth buried Sebba king of the ea≈øt Saxons who died anno domini 633. in a coffin of marble with couer of the ≈øame, his armes the≈øe.
There al≈øo lieth buried Etheldred king of England, King Etheldred burted. the ≈øonne of Edgar who died anno domini 1017. in a coffin of marble with couer of the ≈øame.
There lieth al≈øo Iohn ≈øurnamed Plantaginet in a ≈øtately monument,10. Plantaginet buried. artificially rai≈øed of white free ≈øtone, who≈øe ≈øtile is thus there recorded.

Illustri≈ø≈øimus iacet hic, Iohannes cognomento Plantaginet, Rex Ca≈øtiliae, & Legionis, Dux Lanca≈øtrie, Comes Richmondiae Lece≈øtriae, Lincolnie & Derbiae, locum tenens Aquitaniae, magnus
Sene≈øcallus Angliae obiit anno 22. Ric. 2. Annoque Domini 1399.
Al≈øo there was a Church at the Crotched fryars now conuerted to other v≈øe.
A Church at Augu≈øtine friars founded by Humfrey Bohune E. of H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tford,1253.

A Church called Tho. of Acris neer the great conduct in Cheape founded by Thomas fitz-Theobald in the time of H. 2. who gaue the ≈øame Church to the Mercers for a peece of money,Rec. E. 3. Anno 19. at the ≈øuite of ≈øir Richard Gre≈øham knight, and is now v≈øed for the Mercers hall.

The Temple within Temple barre, The Temple. who≈øe founder is not certainely recorded, yet ≈øome hold it to be that which was called Templum pacis or Concordiae, builded by Dunwallo Mulmutius, about the yeer of the worldes creation 4748. and therein was buried the ≈øame Mulmutius and al≈øo Gorbomanus and others.Galfr. Mon. But ≈øome take the Temple of peace to be that which is now Blackwell-hall. There are in this Temple, many very auncient monuments of famous men, ≈øhaped in Marble armed, their legges cro≈ø≈øe, who≈øe names are not to be gathered, by any in≈øcription, for that, time hath worne it out. The form of this Temple, in the we≈øt, is made circuler, loftely rai≈øed with Marble pillers, ≈øet al≈øo circule ‚Ä¢ ly, ≈øo that it ≈øerueth, the ≈øtudents of the hou≈øe for a walke mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie, & that, for a multitude without di≈øturbance of one by the other, by reuerting. Some ≈øay it was founded by the kings templers which were in England about the yeere of Chri≈øt 1185. but it ≈øeemeth that this Temple is farre more auncient.

There was annexed vnto the Stilliarde an auncient Church called the Temple al≈øo, and after the di≈ø≈øolution thereof,A temple neere the Stilliarde. it was giuen to the ≈øtudents of the Law, bearing the name of White hall, White hall. which belike in regard of the di≈øtance from the other hou≈øes of Law, it was at the length neglected and for≈øaken, which hou≈øe ≈øeemeth to be of the number of the hou≈øes of Chauncery, in the time of Henry the ≈øixt, when Ma≈øter Forte≈øcue compiled his booke of the Lawes of England, wherein he affirmeth that there were in, and neere London, ten Innes of Chauncery, now but eight, in which number of ten, was accompted this White hall, & the Strand Inne, which ≈øtood within the compa≈ø≈øe of Somer≈øet hou≈øe neere the Strand.

The Stilliarde (called of the Gothes the Haun≈øe) ≈øignifieth a place of meeting of the people, Stilliarde why ≈øo called. and e≈øpecially the Marchants of many Countries, and Cities: as of England, France, Denmarke, Mu≈øcouie, Brabant, Flaunders, and many other, where they enterchanged Marchandize by the ≈øundry priueleges and freedomes of many Kings, Dukes, and Princes, which of late yeeres hath by little and little di≈øcontinued. It is not again≈øt rea≈øon, to thinke that the≈øe auncient Temples were erected by the Pagans wherein they offered
≈øacrifices to their countrey gods.Galfr. Mon. For it appeareth by the hi≈øtorie of Ieffery of Monmoth that while C. Alectus Captaine of the Romaine ho≈øt, was thus bu≈øied in his Pagan ≈øacrifice M. Aur. A≈øclepiodotus duke of Cornewall whom the Britons had elected to be their King, came to London, and be≈øieged, and entred it; betweene whom was a hard conflict and Asclepiodotus vanqui≈øhed the Romanes and after be≈øet Gallus another Captaine of the Romanes who remained in the citie, and ouercame him, who with his Romanes being put to the ≈øworde the chiefe Captaine Gallus was ca≈øt into a brooke, which then, and long ≈øince, ran through the Citie, whereof it is ≈øuppo≈øed to be called of the auncient Britons, Walbrooke. Nantgall of the Saxons galenbourne, and of vs at this day Wallbrooke, which runneth neere London ≈øtone which ≈øtone is neere in the mid way betweene Ludd gate and the Tower po≈øterne gate.

There are about this Citie 11. Gates of name, whereof foure are towardes the north, as Alder≈øgate ≈øuppo≈øed to be ≈øo called of the Alders which grew there, and ≈øome holde it to take name of Aldricius the Saxon, it may be ≈øo called of the antiquitie thereof, Aldestgate in the comparatiue degree as Aldgate, Newgate, in the po≈øitiue. Creplegat, So called for that it was the hou≈øe for halt and lame, a ho≈øpitall for creeples and impotent people, it hath beene of late reedified by Edmond Thaa in the yeere of Chri≈øt 1490. Moregate ≈øo called for that it was the pa≈ø≈øage into a moori≈øh, meri≈øh, or watrie ground, which is called Moore fielde, though now brought to be more firme, by the indu≈øtry and charge of a Mayor of London about 180. yeeres pa≈øt. Bu≈øhopes gate builded by certaine Marchantes which traueled into Germaine belonging to the olde Haunce: But it ≈øeemeth by the adiunct that it ≈øhould be builded by a Bu≈øhop.

There are vpon the Thamis three gates, though two of them ≈øeeme rather portes or hauens for ≈øhipes and boates then gates for pa≈ø≈øage, onely the Bridge gate is a thorough fare, or pa≈ø≈øage by hor≈øe and foote, but Billing≈øgate is a harbor or kaye for ≈øhipping, yet hath the name of a gate, for that it was erected fir≈øt like a gate,Galfr. Mon. by Bellinus, and of him called Bellines gate, in the top whereof he cau≈øed to be erected a Pyramis and on the top of it a ve≈ø≈øell of ≈øtone, wherein he appointed the a≈øhes of his brent body to be put after his death. There is al≈øo Dowgate or Dourgate that is Watergate
On the ea≈øt is one gate called Aldegate, ≈øo called of the antiquitie thereof, as M. Camden and others ≈øuppo≈øe.

On the we≈øt are two gates Luddgate or Ludde≈øgate, of LVDD the ≈øuppo≈øed founder, who is ≈øaide to lie interredin the Church of S. Martins within the gate.Anno ante Chri≈øtum 66. This gate was of late yeeres newly builded and made a mo≈øt ≈øtately gate about the yeere of Chri≈øt, 1586. to the great charge of the Citie.Galfr. Mon. Ieffrey of Monmouth reporteth,
that the image of CADWALLO was in bra≈ø≈øe artificially fixed on a bra≈øen hor≈øe, ≈øet on the toppe of this gate,Cadwallo buried in token of a victorie had again≈øt the Saxom: who≈øe body was al≈øo buried in S. Martynes church within the gate.

There was betweene London and Southwarke long time pa≈ø≈øage by ferrie vntill the Citizens cau≈øed a bridge of woode to be erected:Lonlon bridge. after that, in the time of R 1 c. 2. anno 1176. they beganne to build a bridge of ≈øtone, which in the time of king IOHN they mo≈øt artificially fini≈øhed, anno 1209. contriuing it of 20. at ches, and in the mid≈øt a drawe bridge, and vppon the ≈øame bridge on either ≈øide, the hou≈øes ≈øo artificially combined, that the whole bridge ≈øeemeth not onely a mayne and faire ≈øtreete, but men ≈øeeme to pa≈ø≈øe vnder a continuall roofe; the bridge is in height 60. foote, in bredth 30. foote, the arches are in ≈øunder 20. foote, there are vnder the north arch of this bridge, mo≈øt artificially erected certain wheeles or tide myles, which ri≈øe and fall according to the ebs & flouds, and they rai≈øe the water by pypes and counductes ≈øo high that it ≈øerueth ≈øuch citizens hou≈øes in all places of London, as will be≈øtow charge towarde the conducting thereof: The buildings vppon this bridge, on either ≈øide were con≈øumed with fire Anno 1208.Pollid. Virg.
There is neere the three Cranes, a Church called now S. Michaels, ≈øometime Whittingdon Colledge founded by ≈øir Whittingdon, ≈øometime Mayor of London.

There was in that place which is nowe knowne by the name of Blacke-fryers, an auncient and ≈øtrong ca≈øtle, which was called Palatyne, burned in the time of WILLIAM the Conquerour: in the place of which ca≈øtle are at this day erected many faire & beautifull buildings, and here and there the auncient wals and buildings as yet appeare.

On the ea≈øt part of the Citie, is a mo≈øt famous and ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, called the Tower of London, the maine tower whereof, ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe to be builded by IVLIVS CAESAR. It is ≈øtrong and ample, well walled and trenched about, beautified with ≈øundrie builddings, ≈øemblable to a little towne.

There is in Cornehill a mo≈øt famous monument, ≈øtately erected by ≈øir thomas Gre≈øham knight, who named it the Bur≈øe, The Royall Exchange. whereunto afterwarde Queene ELIZABETH gaue the name of Royall exchange; It is the place of the place of the publike meeting of Marchaunts, a≈øwell Engli≈øh as foraine, wherunto twice euery day they dulie re≈øort, the form of the building is quadrate, with walks round the mayne building ≈øupported with pillers of marble, ouer which walkes is a place for the ≈øale of all kinde of wares, richly ≈øtored with varietie of all ≈øorts. It was builded about the yeere 1568.

Leadenhall neere Cornhill was builded by one Sunken Eyre, Leaden hall. about
anno 1444. a place of proui≈øion, or ≈øtore hou≈øe for releefe for the poore in time of dearth.

Manie things might be ≈øpoken of this famous Citie which would too far exceede my purpo≈øe. The Longitude and Latitude of London. It hath latitude 52. degrees, & longitude 19. degrees 15. minuts. It is mo≈øt ≈øweetely ≈øeituate vpon the Thamis, ≈øerued with all kinde of nece≈ø≈øaries mo≈øt commodiou≈ø≈øie. The aire healthfull, it is populous, rich and beautifull, be it al≈øo faithfull, louing and thankfull.

Lodghill D. 16. a hill or fort in Harne≈øey or Horne≈øey parke, and is called Lodghill, Lodghill ≈øometime a fors. for that thereon ≈øometime ≈øtoode a lodge, when the parke was repleni≈øhed with Deare, but it ≈øeemeth by the foundation that it was rather a ca≈øtle, then a lodge, for the hill is at this day trenched with two deepe ditches, now olde and ouergrowne with bu≈øhes: the rubble thereof, as bricke, tile, and Corni≈øh ≈ølate, are in heapes yet to be ≈øeene, which ruines are of great antiquity, as may appeere by the okes, at this day ≈øtanding (aboue 100. yeeres grouth,) vpon the very foundation of the building. It did belong to the bi≈øhop of London, at which place haue beene dated diuers cuidences, ≈øome of which remaine yet in the bi≈øhops rege≈øtrie (as is ≈øaid.)

This parke hath beene repleni≈øhed with ≈øtately timber trees in great aboundance, now with the famous fort fallen to the ground as the Poet ≈øaith,
Euum cuncta rapit furtiu√°que temporamutant.
Naturam, fortem, Nominaque & faciem.

list.item: ** Ludraues, b. 18. a faire hou≈øe ≈øcytuate in a valley neere En≈øeylde chace, belonging vnto
Littleton I. 8. in regard of the quantitie it may be called Linletowne. Linluon.

list.head: M.
list.item:
Mu≈øwell hill, D. 18. called al≈øo Pin≈øenall hill: there was a chapple ≈øometime bearing the name of our Ladie of Mu≈øwell: where now alderman Roe hath erected a proper hou≈øe, the place taketh name of the Well and of the hill, Mou≈øewell hill, for there is on the hil a ≈øpring of faire water, which is now within the compas of the hou≈øe.The Ladie of Mu≈øwell. There was ≈øometime an image of the ladie of Mu≈øwell, whereunto was a continuall re≈øort, in the way of pylgrimage, growing as is (though as I take it) fabulou≈ølie reported, in regard of a great cure which was performed by this water, vpon a king
of Seats, who being ≈øtrangely di≈øea≈øed, was by ≈øome deuine intelligence, adui≈øed to take the water of a Well in England, called Mu≈øwell, which after long ≈øcrutation, and inqui≈øition, this Well was found and performed the cure; ab≈øolutely to denie the cure I dare not, for that the high God hath giuen vertue vnto waters, to heale infirmities, as may appeere by the cure of Naaman the leper, by wa≈øhing him≈øelfe ≈øeauen times in Iordan, 2. King. 1.14. Iohn 5.2. and by the poole Bethe≈øda, which healed the next that ≈øtepped thereinto, after the water was mooued by the angell.
* Mockings, called al≈øo the mannor of Mockings, D. 22. an auncient hou≈øe, of the Lord Comptons, moated about.
Morehatch, A. 20. a hamlet of Enfeylde.
Meerstreete, F. 22. a member of Hackney.

list.head: N.
list.item: Northend, C. 16. a hamlet of Finchley.
** Newington, E. 20. there, the Earle of Oxforde is ≈øometime refident, in a very proper hou≈øe.
Nee≈ødon, or Neu≈ødon, E. 14. a hou≈øe ≈øometime the Elringtons. Northolt lodge, F. 6.
Northolt, F. 8. it ≈øoundeth Northwood, for hols in the Germayne toung ≈øignifieth wood.

list.head: O.
list.item: Olde forde, F. 22. a village taking name of the forde or pa≈ø≈øage at that place, ouer the riuer Lea in time pa≈øt.

* Osterley, or Oy≈øterley, G. 10. the hou≈øe nowe of the ladie Gre≈øhams, Osterley builded. a faire and ≈øtately building of bricke, erected by ≈øir Thomas Gre≈øham knight, Citizen and Marchant aduenturer of London, and fini≈øhed about anno 1577. It ≈øtandeth in a parke by him al≈øo impaled, well wooded, and garni≈øhed with manie faire ponds, which affoorded not onely fi≈øh, and fowle, as ≈øwanes, and other water foule: but al≈øo great v≈øe for milles, as paper milles, oyle milles, and corne milles, all which are now decaied (a corne mill excepted.) In the ≈øame parke was a verie faire Heronrie, for the increa≈øe & pre≈øeruation whereof, ≈øundrie allurements were deui≈øed and ≈øet vp fallen all to ruine.

list.head: P.
list.item: * Pymmes, C. 20. a proper little hou≈øe of the right Honorable Lord Burghley, Lord high Trea≈øurer of England.
Ponder sen, B. 20. a hamlet of Enfeylds.
Peryuale, or Pureuale, F. 10. of this place is ≈øpoken before in the nature of the ≈øoyle of MYDDLESEX.
Paddingwyke, G. 14. for the the ≈øignification of Wyke ≈øee King≈øtonwyke.

Pancras Church, Pancras Church very auncient. F. 20. ≈øtandeth all alone as vtterly for≈øaken, old and wetherbeaten, which for the antiquitie therof, it is thought not to yeeld to Paules in London: about this Church haue bin manie buildings, now decaied, leauing poore Pancras without companie or comfort: yet it is now and then vi≈øited with Kenti≈øh towne and Highgate, which are members therof: but they ≈øeldome come there, for that they haue chappels of ea≈øe within them≈øelues, but when there is a corps to be interred, they are forced to leaue the ≈øame in this for≈øaken church or churchyard, where (no doubt) it re≈øteth as ≈øecure again≈øt the day of re≈øurrection as if it laie in ≈øtately Paules.
Pancras as de≈ø≈øolate as it ≈øtandeth is not for≈øaken of all: aprebrend of Paules accepeth it in right of his office.

list.head: S.

item.p: Syon. H. 12. was built by HENRIE the 5. ≈øometimes a hou≈øe of munkes,Syon builded. but this king expelled them, and int heir place e≈øtabli≈øhed certaine virgins of Bridgets order; and appointed of them ≈øo many with prie≈øts and lay brethren, as were equall with the number of the Apo≈øtles and Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, namelie of virgines 60. prie≈øts 13. deanes, 4. lay brethren 8. which made 13. Apo≈øtles, and 72. Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, vpon whome hauing be≈øtowed ≈øufficient reuenues for their maintenaunce, he made a lawe that they ≈øhould not accept of any other gift, but content them≈øelues with his contribution: and to be≈øtow on the poore what≈øoeuer was aboue that which might rea≈øonably ≈øuffice them.

It is now a hou≈øe of hir Maie≈øties, ≈øtanding mo≈øt plea≈øantly vpon the riuer of Thamys. It was called Syon in remembrance of that hill in Ieru≈øalem, which was called the Holy hill, the mount of the Lord,
the Citie of Dauid, Mouns Syon.

list.item: ** Swakeleys, E. 6. ≈øometime a hou≈øe of the Brockeyes, nowe fir Thomas Sherleyes.
Stanmer little, called al≈øo Whytechurch, D. 10.
South mymmes. A. 14. there is a faire warren of conies of the Lo. Wind≈øores.
Stretford on the bow, F. 24. the bridge ouer the riuer lea,Ree. E. anno 22. is the Bow, and thereof is called Stratford on the bow, neere it, is an olde church, founded by HEN. 2.

item.p:
Stepney, or Stybenhyth,
Sir Henry Collet knight buried or Stibonbeath, F. 22. In the church thereof is buried ≈øir Henry Collet knight, twice Mayor of London, who was father to Iohn Collet, ≈øometime Deane of Paules, who alone builded Paules ≈øchoole, his armes the≈øe.
There lyeth al≈øo the Lady Anne Wentworth wife to Thomas Lord Wentworth, Stepney. Lady Wentworth buried. and daughter to Henry Wentworth E≈øquier. She died the ≈øecond of Sept. 1571.

Sir Thomas Spers knight ≈øometime Controler of the ≈øhipes to H. 8. Dame Margery,
Sir Thomas Spert knight buried. Dame Anne, and Dame Mary his wiues, lie in the Chauncell there, he decea≈øed Anno 1541.
In the north Ile of the ≈øame Church lyeth William Chaldnam e≈øquire,William Chaldnam E≈øquire buried. and Ioan his wife he died the 27. of Sept. Anno 1484.

list.item: Strond, called the Stroud H. 4. a hamlet neere Che≈øwyke, and called the Strond, for that it bordereth ≈øo neere the Thamys.
** Stanwell H. 6. there was the auncient hou≈øe of the Wind≈øores.

item.p: Stanes towne, I. 6. it is called in the Saxon toong. Stana. It ≈øtandeth vpon the Thamis, A market towne kept on the Friday weekly, it is gouerned by two Cun≈øtables and foure Headborrowes: the towne is hir Maie≈øties lande, and the officers cho≈øen by hir Highnes Steward. It ≈øtand eth from the church halfe a mile, and the Church ≈øtandeth vppon a little hill by it ≈øelfe, at if it were bani≈øhed the towne.

Some affirme it to be called Stanes of the Stakes called Coway Stakes, Coway ≈øtakes. which were fixed in the Thamys by the Brytons, to preuent Iulius Cae≈øar, of pa≈ø≈øing his armie through the riuer. There is a towne called Stanes vpon the frontires of Italie in Tyroll, vpon the riuer Inn. Bunn meadow. There is a medow neere Stanes called Bunn meadow, where king IOHN had parley with his barons, and where were ≈øealed betweene them certeyne writings of truce.

Sunburye K. 10. Nica≈øius Yet≈øworth e≈øquire,Nica≈øius Yet≈øworth buried. ≈øometime ≈øecretarie of the French tounge to Queene ELIZABETH: And marie his wife, daughter to Ieames Bow≈øer e≈øquire, lie buried in the ≈øame church.

There was al≈øo buried Daniell Rogers E≈øquire ≈øometime Clerke of the Coun≈øell to Queene ELIZABETH a man of excellent learning,Daniel Rogers buried. and knowledge of toongs, and often imploid in Amba≈ø≈øage into Germainie, Denmarke, Low Countries, &c.

list.head: T.

item.p:
Tottenham or Totheham D. 20. In which Church is buried George Heningham e≈øquire ≈øometime ≈øeruant, & greatly fauored of K. Henrie
the eight he founded there a little ho≈øpitall or alme≈øhou≈øe for three poore widowes.
* At this place the Lord Compton hath a proper ancient hou≈øe.

list.item: Tottenham highcro≈ø≈øe D. 20. a hamlet belonging to Tottenham. and hath this adiunct Highcro≈ø≈øe of a woodden cro≈ø≈øe, there loftly ray≈øed on a little mount of earth.
Twyforde west E. 12. So called of two little brookes or fordes that pa≈ø≈øe neere it. It is a pari≈øh but it hath but one onely hou≈øe thereunto belonging, which is one Iohn Lions Gentleman.
Twyforde east E. 12. belonging to a prebend of Paules.
Touen Court F. 18. belonging to a prebend of Paules.

Thi≈øtle worth or I≈øtleworth H. 12. a place ≈øcytuate vpon the Thamis, not far from whence, betweene it and Worton, Copper and bra≈ø≈øe is a copper and bra≈ø≈øe mill, where it is wrought out of the oare, melted and forged. The oar, or earth, whereof it is contriued, is brought out of Sommer≈øet ≈øhire from Mendip hils, the mo≈øt from Worley hill, manie artificiall deui≈øes there are to be noted in the performance of the worke.

Twickenham I. 12 a pari≈øh ≈øeytuate vpon the Thamis.
Twickenham why ≈øo called. So called either for that, at that place the Thames ≈øemeth to be deuided into two Riuers by rea≈øon of the I≈ølandes there, or el≈øe of the two brookes which neere the towne enter into the Thamis, for Twicknam is as much as Twynam, qua≈øi inter binos amnes ≈øitum, a place ≈øcytuate betweene two riuers.

list.head: V.
list.item: Vxbridge or Woxbridge F. 4. a market towne vpon the edge of the ≈øhire, it is no pari≈øh of it ≈øelfe, but is amember of great Hellingdon, but they haue a Chappell of ea≈øe buylt by Ro. Oliuer, Thomas Mandin, Iohn Palmer, & Iohn Barforde of the ≈øame towne. In the fix and twentith yeere of Henry the ≈øixt. The market is kept on the Thur≈øday. it is gouerned by two Baylifes, two Cun≈øtables, and foure Tythingmen called al≈øo Headborrowes, or as the Saxons call them Borhesealdors the chiefe≈øt or head pledges.

list.head: W.
list.item: * Wirehall E. 20. the hou≈øe of Leeke E≈øquire.

Waltham cro≈ø≈øe A. 20. the farthe≈øt part of this ≈øhire towardes
the north, goeth to the Spittle there.

item.p: Westminster G. 18. Sometime called Thorney of the Saxons √∞orney of ≈øome Dorney but (as I take it) D. is pronounced in ≈øteede of Th. as it is in many other ancient Saxon words,Dorney for Thorney. as Fader, Moder, Broder, for Father, Mother, Brother, which error ari≈øeth belike of the mi≈øtaking of the capitall D. abreauiated thus √ê. which is as much as Th. and the little d. thus abreuiated √∞. for Th. which abreuiations are often taken for the ≈øimple D. and d. by rea≈øon whereof it was called Dorney for √êorney.

This Thorney now We≈øtmin≈øter was an I≈øland inuironed with the Thamis, which deuided it ≈øelfe, and one braunch pa≈ø≈øed betweene Charing cro≈ø≈øe and Kings-≈øtreete, throrowgh S. Ieames parke that now is, Thorney ≈øometime an I≈øland. including Tootehill, and was called Thorney I≈øland, for that it was ouergrowen with bryers and thornes; which Thorney place was in the time of King LVCIVS (as Authors affirme) clen≈øed, about the yeere 186. which LVCIVS is ≈øaide to lay the fir≈øt foundation of the great Temple of S. Peters. S. Peters founded. But Authors greatly vary touching the founders of the ≈øame Temple. Ma≈øter Camden from Sulcardus reporteth that there was fir≈øt a Temple in that place, dedicate to Apollo, which was ouerthrowne by an earth quake in the time of Antonius Pius. Galfr. Mon. It is not vnlike that ≈øuch an Idol Temple was, for it is reported by auncient Authors, that the Troynouantes, or Trinobantes, did ≈øomtime ≈øacrifice Buls, Bullockes, Stags, and ≈øuch like to Diana Tauropolia whom the Gentiles called the Queene of Heauen. Of the ruynes of that Idoll Temple, It is ≈øaid that SEBERTVS King of the ea≈øt Saxons erected another Temple for the ≈øeruice of the liuing God, and con≈øecrated the ≈øame to S. Peter, about the yeere of Chri≈øt 610. neere about the time of the building of Paules. Afterwardes it was de≈øtroyed by the Danes, Math. We≈øtm. and Dunstan Bu≈øhop of London, reedified it about the yeere of Chri≈øt 960. and made there a mona≈øterie for 12. Munckes. Fabian ≈øaith it was builded by the means of ETHELBERT King of Kent, who al≈øo built Paules in London.

I haue heard that there are, or haue beene, records int he ≈øame Abbey, which declare that it was a Church before the Britons receiued the faith, of Chri≈øt, which ≈øhould ≈øeeme to be that Idoll Church of Apollo before LVCIVS time.

After Thorney, it became to be called Westminster, and that in regard of the ≈øcytuation of it we≈øt of London: for on the Tower hill was a mona≈øterie called Eastminster, Ea≈øtmin≈øter. of the ea≈øterly ≈øtanding thereof, which was called al≈øo New abbey, founded by EDW. 3. in the yeee 1359.

There are within this temple, diuers, and ≈øundrie, mo≈øt rare and princely monuments: ≈øome of great antiquitie, ≈øome al≈øo of later times, increa≈øing dailie,Edward confe≈ø≈øor buried. among the re≈øt there lieth EDWARD called al≈øo the Confe≈ø≈øor, who laboured before in this famous worke, and cau≈øed his corps to be interred in the we≈øt part of the Church, which when HEN. 3. had altred, he cau≈øed the body of EDW. to be remooued, to the place where now it re≈øteth, in the ea≈øt part of the Church.

Al≈øo there lieth HEN. 3. Henry the third buried. Tho. Wal≈øing. the fini≈øher of this mo≈øt famous worke, who≈øe tombe is there in mo≈øt kingly manner erected, by the dutifull endeuour and charge of EDW. 1. ≈øonne of the ≈øaid HEN. 3. and for that purpo≈øe, he brought Ia≈øper ≈øtones out of Fraunce, wherewith he beautified his fathers ≈øumptuous ≈øepulchre in anno 1280.
Manie other Kings and Queenes, and per≈øons of high ≈øtate, haue beene there buried, of whome the whole catalogue to re≈øite would be tedious.

There is in this temple a ≈øtone, in forme of a chaire,A ≈øtone chayre in S. Peters Church ≈øometime ≈øeruing, as the throne of the kings of Scots, and wherein they were crowned, which ≈øtone was brought out of Scone in Scotland by EDW. 1. ≈øonne to HEN. 3. about anno 1297. which ≈øtandeth not far from his fathers monument, had in no little price at this day.

There is adioining vnto this famous temple,A chappell of H. 7. in the ea≈øt ende thereof, a chappell erected by HEN. 7. which in regarde of the beautie, and curious contriued worke thereof, is called of Lelande, Orbis miraculum: The wonder of the worlde. In this mirrour of art,Orbis miraculum. and archytect, are many rare and glorious monuments of Kings and Queenes,H. 7. buried. among whom the famous founder HEN. 7. lieth vnder a mo≈øt regall tombe, framed & artificially formed of bras,
richly guilded with pure gold.
Neere this chappell adioining vnto the Thamys, was an olde famous building,Olde pallace. called nowe the Olde pallace, which was con≈øumed with fire, in the time of EDW. the Confe≈ø≈øor.

It was ≈øometime the pallace of king CANVTVS the Dane, Olde pallace king Canutus hou≈øe. al≈øo king of Denmarke, and where he made his abode about the yeere of Chri≈øt, 1035. after his returne from Rome into Englande, who in regard of his quadruplicitie of kingdomes, e≈øteemed him≈øelfe, more than a man mortall: for his Scicophants had ≈øo bewitched him with their inchaunted flatteries, that he deemed him≈øelfe no le≈ø≈øe then a God.The pride of Cauntus. And in this proud conceit on a day he pa≈ø≈øed by the Thamys, which ran by that pallace, at the flowing of the tide, & making ≈øtaie neere the water, the waues ca≈øt foorth ≈øome part of the water towards him, this CANVTVS coniured the waues by his regall commaunde to proceede no farther: the Thamys vnacquainted with this newe God, held on it cour≈øe, flowing as of cu≈øtome it v≈øed to do, and refrained not to a≈ø≈øayle him neere to the knees: whereat this high conceited man as one amazed, begon to tremble, ≈øtarting backe prote≈øting that hee was but a man, though a mightie king. And that he that gouerned tho≈øe waters, was onely worthie to be called a king, and all mortall men, mo≈øt mightie kings, ought to ≈øubiect them vnto him. A woorthie note whereby is ≈øeene howe the almightie Iehouah by his weake creatures, maketh to ≈øtoope the mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant in his owne conceite. Some part of this old pallace is yet ≈øtanding, as S. Stephens chappel, and other buildings vpon the Thamys, neere vnto which is a mo≈øt famous hall, called Westmin≈øter hall, which was ≈øo called for that it was Aularegis, a kings court, but as touching the founder is great varietie.

Some affirme that WILLIAM RVFVS builded it:E. S. de. reb. Br. but M. Camden affirmeth that Hoc quod nunc habemus pretorim RIC. 2. diruto vetustiori extruxit ≈øuaeque habitationi dicauit. RIC. 2. built it and made it his man≈øion hou≈øe. But me thinks it is to be gathered by the words of Thomas Wal≈øingham,
Tho. Wal≈ø. hist. Aug. that Westminster hall was in the time of EDW. the 2. where he ≈øaith, Si ip≈øi Barones cum ≈øuis a≈ø≈øentatoribus in aula Westmonasterii & pleno parliamento venirent &c. whereby it appeereth that Westminster hall and the place of parlament there, was 64. yeeres before RIC. 2. But ≈øome may ≈øay, that the great Hall that nowe is, Tho. Wal≈ø. Ypodigni. New. pag. 49. was not in tho≈øe daies, but the Hall that is nowe called White hall, where the Court of of Requests is now kept. To an≈øwere that the ≈øame Thomas ≈øaith, Rex E. 1. Celebrauit pentico≈øtes in aula magna apud Westmonasterium, whereby he maketh a di≈øtinction betweene tho≈øe two hals, for the White hall was called al≈øo Aula parva, the little hall: which two hals and other buildings thereunto adioining, were v≈øed by RIC.
the 2. who cau≈øed all controuer≈øies there to be heard, (who as all other kings) in tho≈øe daies ≈øat in iudgemeÃÑt: Kings ≈øat in Court to heare and determine cau≈øes. & wher≈øoeuer the king was in per≈øon, there was the place of hearing, and determining cau≈øes: ≈øauing that the common plees were by HEN. 3. appointed to be heard in a place certaine, as appeereth in magna Charta, where it is ≈øaide, Communia placita non ≈øequntur Curiam nostram. Sed teneantur in aliquo loco certo. But at this day all cau≈øes of what≈øoeuer nature, for the mo≈øt part are heard and determinable, at this place as a place certeine.S. Stephens chappelli

Betweene Westminster hall, and the Thamys is a chapple of S. Stephens: ≈øometime verie beautifull, though now in the outwarde ≈øhewe ≈øomething defaced: It was reedefied and augmented by EDW. 3. when he came victor out of Fraunce, about the yeere of Chri≈øt 1347.
Westminster had ≈øometime a hou≈øe of monkes, who were remooued thence by HEN. 7. and a Deane with certaine Prebends e≈øtabli≈øhed. We≈øtmin≈øter a Bu≈øhops ≈øea.

In the time of EDWARD 6. it was made a bi≈øhops See, but ≈øhortlie after it came againe to a Deane and Prebends; Againe Queene MARIE ordeined there an Abbot and his munkes, who continued not manie yeeres, but were againe cut off by acte of Parleament: La≈øtly our mo≈øt gratious Queene ELIZABETH made it a collegiate Church: in≈øtituting a Deane, twelue Prebends, twelue well de≈øeruing ≈øoldiers, and fortie ≈øchollers: who are thereby termed The Queenes ≈øchollers, who, as they become woorthie, are preferred to the Vniuer≈øities. All which pupils, as long as they continue in this colledge, are vnder the Deane, now D. Goodman. Alex. Neuell. Norwic.

Alexander Neuell Norwic. affirmeth that the Bi≈øhops of Caunterburie, in the time of RIC. the 1. did make their mo≈øt abode at Westminster, as they do nowe at Lambeth, or Lomehith, and had ouer again≈øt the ≈øchoole that nowe is, a ≈øtately hou≈øe:Lelande. yet Lelande affirmeth the contrary, who ≈øaith, that the Bi≈øhops of Caunterburie haue continued at Lambeth ≈øince the Normanes comming into this land.

There is an auncient monument within the libertie of Westminster, Charing cro≈ø≈øe. called Charing cro≈ø≈øe, erected about the yeere of Chri≈øt,Tho. Wal≈ø.1290. by EDW. 1. in memoriall of the death of Elineor his Queene, who died at Hardlie neere Lincolne, & was buried in We≈øtmin≈øter.

The libertie of Westminster extendeth to Temple bar: Temple bar. ≈øo calcalled of the Temple within the ≈øame bar, and is called the bar for that it ≈øtoppeth and barreth the Mayor of London, as al≈øo the Magi≈øtrates of Westminster, that neither intrude vpon other. This bar or gate was throwne downe by the Kenti≈øh rebels, in the time of RIC. 2.
Within the libertie of Westminster are fower pari≈øh Churches,Pari≈øh Churches in the libertie of We≈øtmin≈øter. be≈øides S. Peters, namelie,
S. Margarets
S. Martynes neere Charing cro≈ø≈øe.
The Sauoy Church.
S. Clements, called Saint Clements Dacorum, or Saint Clements Danes.

In the time of ≈øuper≈øtition there was in Westminster, a place called the Sanctuary, The Sanctuary. of an old Mo≈øaical ryte, v≈øed among the I≈øraelites, among whom euery tribe had certaine cities, and places of refuge, to which malefactors might repaire, and for a time be protected from the rigor of the law.
There was at Westminster kept a ≈øtaple of wooll,The Woul≈øtaple. and is at this daie, called the Woolstaple, e≈øtabli≈øhed in the time of EDWARD the 3.

The Sauoye was fir≈øt built (as M. Stowe hath recorde) by Peter Earle of Sauoy, The Sauoy. who was after made Earle of Richmonde, by HENRIE the 3. who called it the Sauoy after his Countrie. But Poll. Virg. Pollid. Virg. alloweth him not Earle of Sauoy, but calleth him Petrus ≈øebaudien≈øis: Peter a Sauoyan, or of the countrie of Sauoy, who as the ≈øame Poll. affirmeth, buylt the ≈øame, and called it the Sauoy, of his natiue Countrey Sauoye. It was belonging vnto the Duke of Lanca≈øter, in the time of RIC. the 2. in who≈øe time it was wa≈øted, burned, and ≈øpoyled by the Kenti≈øh rebels, about the yere 1381. It was reedefied by HEN. 7. by who≈øe la≈øt will, it was intended to be fini≈øhed, and made an Ho≈øpitall, for the reliefe of a 100. poore people, which was perfourmed by the mo≈øt famous HEN. the 8. his ≈øonne, and ≈øufficiently furni≈øhed with lande, and reuenues, for the maintenance thereof.

Queene ELIZABETH hath within the precincts of this Citie three faire and plea≈øant pallaces:How≈øes of Queene Elizabeths within We≈øtmin≈øter. namely White hall, begun by Cardinall Wool≈øey, and fini≈øhed, with manie mo≈øt princely delights, by HEN. 8. S. Ieames, erected by the ≈øame king HEN. 8. and Somer≈øet hou≈øe builded by the Duke of Somer≈øet about the yeere of Chri≈øt 1549.

There are other hou≈øes worthy to be remembred within this libertie of Westminster as Burghley hou≈øe, Burgley hou≈øe. founded and erected by the right honorable S. William Cycell knight, Lord Burghley, Lord high trea≈øoror of England.

Durham or Dunelme hou≈øe ≈øometime belonging to the Bi≈øhop of Durham,
Durham hou≈øe builded. it was builded by one Anthony Becke in the time of RICHARD the third. Other famous hou≈øes of nobility are in this precinct, which to mention I omit for breuitie.

item.p: This Citie of Westmin≈øter is knowne to haue no generall trade whereby releefe might be admini≈øtred vnto the common ≈øort, as by Marchandize, clothing, or ≈øuch like, whereby the common wealth of a Citie is maineteined, and the inferiour people ≈øet to worke, had they not therefore ≈øome other meanes, the common ≈øort could nor be ≈øu≈øteined.The chiefe meane whereby We≈øtmin≈øter is releeued.

The fir≈øt and principall meane whereby they are releeued, is hir Maie≈øties re≈øidence at White hall, or S. Ieames, whence if hir
grace be long ab≈øent, the poore people forthwith complaine of penury and want, of a hard and mi≈øerable world. And therefore doe the people in manner generally ≈øeeme to power forth dayly petitions, that it might plea≈øe God to draw hir Maie≈øtie to be re≈øident at one of the≈øe places, whereat they reioyce and fare long the better. The like de≈øire of hir Royall pre≈øence haue other places, where hir Maie≈øties Pallaces are placed. And hir Maie≈øtie in gracious con≈øideration of their e≈øtates, doth vi≈øit them as it were Alternis vicebus, by turne at hir highnes plea≈øure, more for the comfort and releefe of the poore people, then for hir owne priuate delight. Therefore yee Citizens of Westminster, and other, what≈øoeuer, forget not to be thankefull to the the Almightie for hir Royall pre≈øence, hartely praying the King of Kings, to maintaine hir a pro≈øpering Queene long and many yeeres, and euery faithfull hart will ioyne with you, hauing al≈øo the benefite of hir ble≈ø≈øed inclination.

The ≈øeconde meane whereby this poore Citie is maintained,The ≈øecond meane, the Tearmes. and the people releeued, is by the fower Termes in the yeere, for it hath plea≈øed God to e≈øtabli≈øh there, the place where Iu≈øtice, lawe, and euerie mans right is (God graunt it) with equall ballance, indifferently admini≈øtred: whereunto great multitudes of people, v≈øually flocke, who≈øe re≈øort although the Citie enioie but in the forenoone, yet yeeldeth their pre≈øence, manie pence to the poore towne.

There was in the time of EDW. 1. a di≈øcontinuance of the lawe,The hearing of cau≈øes remooued to Yorke. in this Citie, and was thence remooued to Yorke, where it continued, ≈øeauen yeeres after reduced to the former place. It hath beene often di≈øcontinued by the disfauour of Princes, and their conceiued di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt the inhabitants of the place, for di≈øobedience, as a generall puni≈øhment. Receiue this ye inhabitants of Westminster, as a nece≈ø≈øarie premonition, that ye re≈øt carefull and vigilant, lea≈øt the king of kings mooue her Maie≈øtie to place the determination of cau≈øes el≈øe where, which now is vnto you no ≈ømall ≈øupport.

The third and la≈øt meane (though it come ≈øeldome) is that great and generall convencion of all the e≈øtates of this lande,The third mean, the Parliament. the high Court of Parleament, which draweth vnto it a great acce≈ø≈øe of noble per≈øons, and others, to the place of a≈ø≈øemblie, which is al≈øo ≈øet mo≈øt gratiou≈øly within this Citie, which yeeldeth no ≈ømall releefe vnto the ≈øame, which al≈øo (as is recorded in hi≈øtories) hath beene holden at diuers other places in this land.

It is not yet forgotten,The tearme remooued to Hertford. no doubt, how the God offended, vi≈øited not onely this Citie, but al≈øo London, with a dangerous late infection, in≈øomuch as the la≈øt Michaelmas Terme was remooued to
Hertforde ca≈øtle, which pinched the poore, and made the rich to complaine, in both the≈øe Cities: yet a more gentle forewarning of his di≈øplea≈øure he cannot ≈øhew, who longing for new obedience in vs, calleth vs by diuers meanes, and without ≈øpeedie and harty repentance we ≈øhall likewi≈øe peri≈øh.

div.p: I craue patience though I haue not giuen to euerie man his addition of E≈øquire or Gent. for that I may ea≈øely erre therein, without the e≈øpeciall aide of an expert Herault.

div.head: To the right wor≈øhipful M. WILLIAM WAADE E≈øquire, one of the clearks of hir Maiesties mo≈øt Honorable priuie Coun≈øell.
div.p: SIR, I cannot re≈øt vnreadie in de≈øire, to yeeld requitall of your aide extended towards the publication of this fir≈øt part of my SPECVLVM BRITANNIAE: wherin I mu≈øt, and do thankfullie acknowledge your good inclination not towards me onely, but to all ≈øuch as indeuour matters tending to publike good. In lieu therfore of a farther faithful recompence, accept, I be≈øeech you, my willing indeuor, vntil time afforde ablenes to make better repay.
